low.question: What does GDP measure in an economy?
options: Total value of final goods and services produced
Total value of all financial transactions
low.answer: Total value of final goods and services produced

low.question: What is inflation commonly defined as?
options: A sustained rise in the general price level
A one-time increase in a single product's price
A rise in the stock market index
low.answer: A sustained rise in the general price level

low.question: What does unemployment rate measure?
options: Share of labor force actively seeking work without a job
Share of population below poverty line
low.answer: Share of labor force actively seeking work without a job

low.question: What is a market defined by many sellers and identical products?
low.answer: Perfect competition

low.question: What is opportunity cost?
options: Value of the best foregone alternative
low.answer: Value of the best foregone alternative

low.question: What does the term 'demand' refer to in economics?
options: Consumers' willingness and ability to buy
low.answer: Consumers' willingness and ability to buy

low.question: What is supply in economic terms?
options: Quantity producers are willing to sell at various prices
low.answer: Quantity producers are willing to sell at various prices

low.question: What is meant by 'price elasticity of demand'?
options: Responsiveness of quantity demanded to price changes
Change in price when demand rises
low.answer: Responsiveness of quantity demanded to price changes

low.question: What is fiscal policy?
options: Government decisions on taxation and spending
low.answer: Government decisions on taxation and spending

low.question: What is monetary policy?
options: Central bank actions to control money supply and interest rates
low.answer: Central bank actions to control money supply and interest rates

low.question: What is a tariff?
low.answer: A tax on imports

low.question: What is a subsidy?
options: Government financial support to reduce costs
low.answer: Government financial support to reduce costs

low.question: What does 'liquidity' describe?
options: Ease of converting an asset to cash
low.answer: Ease of converting an asset to cash

low.question: What is a bond?
options: A debt instrument promising repayment with interest
An ownership share in a company
low.answer: A debt instrument promising repayment with interest

low.question: What is inflation measured by the CPI?
options: Consumer Price Index tracks a basket's price changes
Corporate Profit Index tracks firm profits
Currency Purchasing Index tracks exchange rates
low.answer: Consumer Price Index tracks a basket's price changes

low.question: What is GDP per capita intended to represent?
low.answer: Average output per person

low.question: What is a monopoly?
low.answer: Single seller dominating a market

low.question: What is meant by 'comparative advantage'?
options: Lower opportunity cost of producing a good than others
Higher absolute production of a good
low.answer: Lower opportunity cost of producing a good than others

low.question: What are public goods characterized by?
low.answer: Nonexcludability and nonrivalry

low.question: What is an externality?
options: A cost or benefit affecting third parties
low.answer: A cost or benefit affecting third parties

low.question: What does 'real GDP' adjust for?
low.answer: Inflation

low.question: What is opportunity cost of attending college?
low.answer: Earnings forgone by not working

low.question: What is 'marginal cost'?
options: Cost of producing one additional unit
low.answer: Cost of producing one additional unit

low.question: What is 'marginal utility'?
options: Extra satisfaction from consuming one more unit
low.answer: Extra satisfaction from consuming one more unit

low.question: What is a trade deficit?
low.answer: Imports exceed exports

low.question: What is 'capital' in economics?
options: Machinery, tools, and buildings used in production
Natural resources like oil and timber
low.answer: Machinery, tools, and buildings used in production

low.question: What is 'human capital'?
low.answer: Skills and knowledge of workers

low.question: What does 'price floor' imply?
low.answer: Minimum legal price above equilibrium

low.question: What does 'price ceiling' imply?
options: Maximum legal price set below equilibrium
low.answer: Maximum legal price set below equilibrium

medium.question: Which component belongs to GDP using expenditure approach?
medium.answer: Investment spending by firms

medium.question: What does CPI 'basket' represent?
options: Typical goods and services purchased by consumers
medium.answer: Typical goods and services purchased by consumers

medium.question: Which measure excludes volatile food and energy prices?
medium.answer: Core inflation

medium.question: What is the natural rate of unemployment?
options: Unemployment when labor market is at long-run equilibrium
medium.answer: Unemployment when labor market is at long-run equilibrium

medium.question: What does the Phillips Curve originally show?
options: Inverse short-run relationship between inflation and unemployment
Direct relationship between inflation and GDP growth
No link between wages and unemployment
medium.answer: Inverse short-run relationship between inflation and unemployment

medium.question: What is price elasticity greater than one called?
medium.answer: Elastic demand

medium.question: Which tax is progressive by design?
options: Income tax with rising marginal rates
medium.answer: Income tax with rising marginal rates

medium.question: What does GDP deflator measure versus CPI?
options: Prices of all domestically produced goods and services
Prices of imported consumer goods only
medium.answer: Prices of all domestically produced goods and services

medium.question: What is market failure due to external costs called?
medium.answer: Negative externality

medium.question: Which policy describes lowering taxes to stimulate growth?
medium.answer: Supply-side policy

medium.question: What is the Laffer Curve concept about?
options: Tax rate and revenue non-linear relationship
medium.answer: Tax rate and revenue non-linear relationship

medium.question: Which term describes government borrowing reducing private investment?
medium.answer: Crowding out

medium.question: What is meant by 'money supply M1'?
medium.answer: Currency and checking deposits

medium.question: What is velocity of money?
options: Frequency money circulates to buy goods and services
Rate banks lend to each other overnight
medium.answer: Frequency money circulates to buy goods and services

medium.question: What does 'real interest rate' equal approximately?
options: Only the central bank target rate
medium.answer: Nominal rate minus inflation rate

medium.question: What is meant by 'moral hazard' in finance?
medium.answer: Insured parties taking greater risks

medium.question: Which concept describes benefits from larger production scale?
medium.answer: Economies of scale

medium.question: What is deadweight loss associated with?
options: Market inefficiency from price controls or taxes
medium.answer: Market inefficiency from price controls or taxes

medium.question: Which account records exports and imports of goods and services?
medium.answer: Current account

medium.question: What is 'exchange rate depreciation'?
options: Domestic currency loses value relative to foreign currency
Domestic currency gains value relative to foreign currency
Fixed exchange rate restored by government
medium.answer: Domestic currency loses value relative to foreign currency

medium.question: Which indicator tracks wholesale prices before retail?
medium.answer: Producer Price Index

medium.question: What is Ricardian equivalence about?
options: Private saving offsets government borrowing for future taxes
Monetary policy having no effect on output
medium.answer: Private saving offsets government borrowing for future taxes

medium.question: What is adverse selection in insurance markets?
options: High-risk individuals more likely to buy insurance
medium.answer: High-risk individuals more likely to buy insurance

medium.question: What does Gini coefficient measure?
medium.answer: Income or wealth inequality

medium.question: What is the primary role of a central bank?
options: Manage monetary policy and financial stability
medium.answer: Manage monetary policy and financial stability

medium.question: What is fractional reserve banking?
options: Banks keep a fraction of deposits as reserves
Banks hold all deposits as reserves
medium.answer: Banks keep a fraction of deposits as reserves

medium.question: What is the purpose of a tariff quota?
options: Limit imports with preferential tariff rates up to quota
medium.answer: Limit imports with preferential tariff rates up to quota

medium.question: What is meant by 'stagflation'?
options: High inflation with stagnant economic growth
medium.answer: High inflation with stagnant economic growth

medium.question: Which metric shows labor participation?
medium.answer: Labor force participation rate

medium.question: What is the intuition behind Pareto efficiency?
options: No one can be made better off without making someone worse off
medium.answer: No one can be made better off without making someone worse off

hard.question: Which definition best describes the natural rate hypothesis in macroeconomics?
options: Output returns to potential and unemployment to natural rate regardless of money growth
Fiscal deficits cause permanent growth increases
hard.answer: Output returns to potential and unemployment to natural rate regardless of money growth

hard.question: What is the difference between GDP measured by income and expenditure approaches?
options: They should be equal theoretically, differing only by statistical discrepancy
Income approach excludes government spending entirely
hard.answer: They should be equal theoretically, differing only by statistical discrepancy

hard.question: In open economy, what does the Marshall-Lerner condition describe?
options: Currency depreciation improves trade balance if sum of elasticities exceeds one
hard.answer: Currency depreciation improves trade balance if sum of elasticities exceeds one

hard.question: Which concept captures the short-run trade-off between inflation and unemployment?
hard.answer: Short-run Phillips Curve

hard.question: What is 'seigniorage' in public finance?
options: Revenue from issuing money net of production costs
hard.answer: Revenue from issuing money net of production costs

hard.question: Which model formalizes consumption smoothing under certainty with future income known?
hard.answer: Permanent Income Hypothesis

hard.question: What is the principal-agent problem in economics?
options: Agent's incentives diverge from principal's objectives
Principal cannot contractually hire an agent
Agents always act in principals' best interest
hard.answer: Agent's incentives diverge from principal's objectives

hard.question: What does the Modigliani-Miller theorem assert for perfect markets?
options: Capital structure does not affect firm value
Only debt financing maximizes firm value
hard.answer: Capital structure does not affect firm value

hard.question: Which measure adjusts nominal GDP to remove price changes using chained weights?
hard.answer: Chain-weighted real GDP

hard.question: What does the Heckscher-Ohlin theorem predict about trade patterns?
options: Countries export goods intensive in their abundant factors
Trade depends only on technology differences
hard.answer: Countries export goods intensive in their abundant factors

hard.question: What is the economic meaning of a liquidity trap?
options: Interest rates near zero making monetary policy ineffective
Excessive inflation despite high interest rates
Unlimited fiscal borrowing crowding out investment
hard.answer: Interest rates near zero making monetary policy ineffective

hard.question: Which equation defines the money multiplier under fractional reserve banking?
options: Money multiplier equals 1 divided by reserve ratio
Money multiplier equals reserve ratio times base money
Money multiplier equals M1 minus M2
hard.answer: Money multiplier equals 1 divided by reserve ratio

hard.question: What is 'Ricardian equivalence' implication for government deficits?
options: Consumers offset deficits by saving for future taxes, limiting stimulus
Deficits always stimulate aggregate demand fully
Deficits reduce real interest rates permanently
hard.answer: Consumers offset deficits by saving for future taxes, limiting stimulus

hard.question: Which test identifies cointegration among nonstationary time series in macroeconometrics?
hard.answer: Engle-Granger or Johansen cointegration tests

hard.question: What is Main idea of the Tinbergen Rule in policy design?
options: Number of independent policy instruments must equal policy targets
Policy tools should always be monetary
hard.answer: Number of independent policy instruments must equal policy targets

hard.question: What is the practical implication of the Mundell-Fleming model under fixed exchange rates?
options: Fiscal policy more effective; monetary policy ineffective at influencing output
hard.answer: Fiscal policy more effective; monetary policy ineffective at influencing output

hard.question: Which concept describes diminishing returns to a single input holding others fixed?
hard.answer: Law of diminishing marginal returns

hard.question: What does the 'Sunk cost fallacy' cause in decision making?
options: Persisting with projects due to irrecoverable past costs
Ignoring all past investments when deciding
hard.answer: Persisting with projects due to irrecoverable past costs

hard.question: Which indicator signals potential recession when inverted?
options: Yield curve inversion between long and short-term rates
hard.answer: Yield curve inversion between long and short-term rates

hard.question: What does the Stolper-Samuelson theorem connect in trade theory?
options: Trade liberalization raises return to abundant factor and lowers return to scarce factor
Exports reduce domestic capital returns uniformly
hard.answer: Trade liberalization raises return to abundant factor and lowers return to scarce factor

hard.question: What is 'quantitative easing' central banks do?
options: Purchase long-term securities to inject liquidity and lower yields
hard.answer: Purchase long-term securities to inject liquidity and lower yields

hard.question: Which metric captures total factor productivity in growth accounting?
options: Residual not explained by measured labor and capital inputs
Sum of labor and capital inputs
hard.answer: Residual not explained by measured labor and capital inputs

hard.question: How does an open-economy IS curve shift with expansionary fiscal policy under floating exchange rates?
options: Shifts right and may appreciate currency, partially offsetting demand boost
Shifts left causing depreciation and more output
Remains unchanged because monetary policy dominates
hard.answer: Shifts right and may appreciate currency, partially offsetting demand boost

hard.question: What is 'transfer pricing' concern in multinational taxation?
options: Profit shifting via intra-firm prices to minimize taxes
hard.answer: Profit shifting via intra-firm prices to minimize taxes

hard.question: Which phenomenon explains why poorer countries sometimes grow faster catching up technologically?
hard.answer: Conditional convergence under similar policies

hard.question: What does the term 'haircut' mean in sovereign debt restructuring?
options: Creditor accepts a reduction in principal or payments
Government imposes a sudden inflation tax
hard.answer: Creditor accepts a reduction in principal or payments

hard.question: Which test determines whether a tax is progressive across income distribution?
options: Comparing average tax rates rising with income quantiles
Checking whether marginal rates equal zero
Verifying that everyone pays same percentage
hard.answer: Comparing average tax rates rising with income quantiles

hard.question: What is the concept of 'time inconsistency' in policy?
options: Policymakers change optimal plan later due to shifting incentives
hard.answer: Policymakers change optimal plan later due to shifting incentives

hard.question: Which factor most directly explains the liquidity preference theory for interest rates?
options: Demand for money balances depends on interest foregone from holding money
Fiscal deficits set long-term rates exclusively
hard.answer: Demand for money balances depends on interest foregone from holding money

hard.question: What is the fundamental result of the Sonnenschein-Mantel-Debreu theorem?
options: Aggregate excess demand can take almost any continuous shape, limiting uniqueness of equilibria
Markets always have a unique stable equilibrium
hard.answer: Aggregate excess demand can take almost any continuous shape, limiting uniqueness of equilibria

hard.question: Which policy implication follows from Haavelmo's theorem about government spending?
options: Government spending financed by money creation can raise demand; financing matters for multipliers
All financing methods result in zero multiplier
Tax cuts always have larger multipliers than spending
hard.answer: Government spending financed by money creation can raise demand; financing matters for multipliers

hard.question: What characterizes a Ponzi scheme from national fiscal perspective?
options: New borrowing used solely to service earlier debt, unsustainable without growth
hard.answer: New borrowing used solely to service earlier debt, unsustainable without growth

hard.question: Which statistic reflects income mobility between Lorenz curve cross-sections?
options: Transition matrices or mobility indices complement static Gini measures
hard.answer: Transition matrices or mobility indices complement static Gini measures

hard.question: What is the role of contingent convertible bonds (CoCos) in bank regulation?
options: Convert to equity under stress to absorb losses
hard.answer: Convert to equity under stress to absorb losses

hard.question: How does a country achieve a real exchange rate depreciation without nominal change?
options: Domestic prices fall relative to foreign prices
Central bank raises nominal interest rates
hard.answer: Domestic prices fall relative to foreign prices
